document.masterDocTitle: Redescription of the fig wasp genus Sycophilodes Joseph (Chalcidoidea: Pteromalidae: Epichrysomallinae) with description of a new species from India

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Redescription of the fig wasp genus Sycophilodes Joseph (Chalcidoidea: Pteromalidae: Epichrysomallinae) with description of a new species from India

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined. 14 ♀,
20 ♂
card mounted; series ♀, ♂ preserved in 70 % ethanol: INDIA , New Delhi, IARI , Pusa campus,
28 ° 38 ' 28.9428 "N
077° 10 '09.3936"E
,
24 .III. 2012
, ex
Ficus benghalensis
L., collector A. Pramanik, deposited in National Pusa Collection, IARI , New Delhi.

Colour . Body generally honey coloured; antenna pale brown; eyes red, ocelli translucent; interocellar area black; vertex darker than face; apical tooth of mandible dark brown; mesosoma dorsally brownish black, wings hyaline, veins dark brown; legs pale yellow, claws dark brown; first two gastral terga with median brownish black patches; ovipositor sheath brownish black.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–10.
Sycophilodes moniliformis Joseph
♀. 1, habitus, lateral view; 2, head, frontal view; 3, head, dorsal view; 4, antenna; 5, mandible; 6, mesosoma, lateral view; 7, mesosoma, dorsal view; 8, propodeum; 9, fore wing venation; 10, postmarginal and stigmal vein of fore wing (enlarged).

FIGURES 11–20.
Sycophilodes moniliformis Joseph
♂. 11, habitus, lateral view; 12, head, frontal view; 13, head, dorsal view; 14, antenna; 15, mandible; 16, mesosoma, lateral view; 17, mesosoma, dorsal view; 18, propodeum; 19, fore wing venation; 20, postmarginal and stigmal vein of fore wing (enlarged).

subSubSection.paragraph: Metasoma . Gaster 1.4 × longer than wide. Hypopygium 1.1 × as long as hind tibia, apical quarter with 4 or 5 pairs of median setae.
Colour . Mesosoma mid-dorsally with brownish black patches; first three gastral terga deep brown.
General body sculpture and pilosity . Pronotum rather setose.
Variation. Body length: 2.4–2.7 mm for female, 2.0– 2.4 mm for male. Mid-dorsal black patch on mesosoma sometimes relatively pale and narrow.
Distribution. India (New Delhi).
